A list:

1. Filling glass jars with the sound of sleep.
2. Sliding pieces of light under bedroom doors.
3. (unfinished)




<lj-embed id="59"/>





...And I saw her glowing.
In the dark woods,
I saw her smiling.
We were crying
And I saw her laughing.
In our sadness,
I saw her dancing...
</lj-cut>

It was a cloudy afternoon with heavy grey clouds hanging above you. Was your house on fire?

I'm just another snowman standing in the rain and sleet. I've had that dream too.

This book is hopeless. Why do you like things that are hopeless? Cleaning toilets and tossing handfuls of dirt. Drones and hums; plaster and plaster. Side profile, sleeping in the car. Pretend we're fairies. I'm a girl fairy and my name is Larulee. And you're a boy fairy and your name is Teeteree. Pretend when we're fairies we fight each other. And I say "stop hitting me or I'll die!" And you hit me again, and I say "now I have to die." And you say "but I'll miss you". And I say "but I have to." And you'll have to wait a million years to see me again. And I'll be put in a box. And all I'll need is a glass of water and lots of tiny pieces of pizza. And the box will have wings like an airplane. And you ask "where will it take you?" "Home," I say.

...and sometimes your eyes were so close that I couldn't help but look right through them. ---- Fly Piece This piece was first performed in Tokyo, Naiqua Gallery, 1964. Each person who attended the night flew in his/her own way. It was performed again in London at The Jeanette Cochrane Theatre by the audience who came up on the stage and jumped off the different leveled ladders prepared for them. ---- Sunbeams will soon smile through Good mornin', good mornin' to you! And you, and you, and you!

Some nights it's good just to eat cookies with the Lolita soundtrack playing, clicking though Facebook photo albums friends are tagged in, discovering that they somehow inexplicably know your Grade 4 teacher who retired 15 years ago, and that she, who must be in her late 70s, also has an account. I'm still trying to figure out first if I should add her, and if I do, what to say in that friend request message. I want to get my class photo from that year, scan it and make it my profile picture first though. Because I'm always slightly surprised to find out that people I used to know in junior school grew up too, and look nothing like the 8-year-old versions of themselves I had in my memory. Small world, this internet.

What have I been doing...hmm. I won a trip to Ottawa with some friends for providing pictures and the music for a video contest we put together for the Canadian Revenue Agency. The church picnic this year was the rainiest it's ever been, but I got some pretty great pictures out of it. I went to my first real big top circus! But what was mostly taking up my time these past few months was this thing called shadow casting; acting out a movie on a stage while it plays behind on the screen. I auditioned on a whim back in April and was cast as the lawyer in Jurassic Park as part of the Toronto Fringe Festival, but I had no idea how positive and life-affirming and all that good stuff it would be. The 20ish people involved in the production are all really wonderful, and now, if even a few days pass where I don't see them I start to miss them. Having zero theatre experience going into all this, I wasn't sure how things would go, or what to expect really. Now that I've been depantsed by a hairy man in a tight black dress with a harness and T-rex claws, I feel I'm ready for anything. Here are some pictures from the shadow cast of Blue Velvet Buffy The Vampire Slayer Repo! The Genetic Opera The Rocky Horror Picture Show and of course JURASSIC PARK! We built some last-minute props like cow pinatas and parking lot signs in the park behind the theatre just before the show.... and danced to 80s music down the street after. I was at the Bloor Cinema 14 out of 31 days in July, and won't soon forget the time I spent there. I also had a Twin Peaks-themed birthday party, but didn't take any pictures because I was too busy eating donuts and cherry pie and drinking black coffee. And I got let go from my job at the architecture firm and now work part-time shrink wrapping adult diapers in a warehouse. Now I'm off to see a movie about Nazi zombies called Dead Snow. Should be pretty amazing.

In the swallow of dark, we are sightless visionaries. Shedding faculties. False attribution. Categorical mistakes. Choking on armpits and excess. Huffing words like fuck and oh, god. We ripple and swell. Spit. No. Swallow. No. Plunge and scour. Hold on.

Peripherals dizzied. Are we there yet? According to the semicircular canals of our inner ears, we're still moving. See, anastomosis belies endpoints.

Recognizance is disorienting: motion sick.

You pull hard, eyelids over eyeballs. Run for the door. And trip every time, sneaker toe caught on a door lip.

Later, you call me to say, "There is water everywhere."

I believe you.


from The Night Is A Mouth by Lisa Foad
I started an album cover blog: http://analbumcoverfor7000.blogspot.com/ It was just a matter of time, really...

I was in a school or hospital hallway. I slipped on a drink someone had spilled on the floor and I landed on my back and cracked my head on the ground. Then I was in a small room with fluorescent lights a trampoline floor. A girl who I used to know quite well surprised me by appearing in the room to my right. "We have much to talk about," she said, but I was bleeding and couldn't respond. She lay down beside me with her head brushing up against my hand and I closed my eyes.

somewhere i have never traveled, gladly beyond any experience, your eyes have their silence: in your most frail gesture are things which enclose me, or which i cannot touch because they are too near your slightest look easily will unclose me though i have closed myself as fingers, you open always petal by petal myself as Spring opens (touching skilfully, mysteriously) her first rose or if your wish be to close me, i and my life will shut very beautifully, suddenly, as when the heart of this flower imagines the snow carefully everywhere descending; nothing which we are to perceive in this world equals the power of your intense fragility: whose texture compels me with the color of its countries, rendering death and forever with each breathing (i do not know what it is about you that closes and opens; only something in me understands the voice of your eyes is deeper than all roses) nobody, not even the rain, has such small hands e. e. cummings

My company's art/architecture installation closed yesterday. Nearly 1000 clear tags of people's descriptions of their sacred space were ceremonially cut from their glowing rods and inserted into numbered envelopes below. Now I am scanning them all in and categorizing the responses. We might be making a book!
it's my very first zine! very exciting. i'm distributing them tonight by sneaking them into the free newspaper boxes in downtown toronto. pick up your copy here!

After thinking about it for several years, I'm finally starting up my very own zine! I've called it "Consolation Prize" after the Orange Juice song, and the first issue is coming out in two Thursdays. At this point, the content is pretty much anything goes, although I'm staying away from long pieces of writing for now. The types of things I have so far include: comics, collages, extracts from childhood love letters and teenage break-up letters, found photos, and even a Vice Magazine Dos and Don'ts send-off among other things. I also set up an email account to accommodate anonymous submissions, which has been working well so far. If any of you have something you'd care to have printed in a small photocopied zine and distributed in downtown Toronto via the newspaper boxes of a couple free weeklies, (as well as online,) please let me know! This is the facebook group I'm using to co-ordinate things and distribute the zine as a pdf: But if you don't have an account, anonymous submissions work like this. Log into Gmail with username consolationprizesubmissions@gmail.com password anonymous and reply to the email from me in the inbox. Since the issue is coming out in just over a week, I'm asking for submissions to be in by this Saturday around noonish. But if I receive something later, it'll likely go into the next issue in two months. This is the plan at least. If I get a few people on board to compile, edit, or do layout I could probably manage a monthly, but for now it'll be every other month.
from Rid of Me by Kate Schatz

"What uniform can I wear to hide my heavy heart? It is too heavy. It will always show." Jaques felt himself growing gloomy again. He was well aware that to live on Earth a man must follow its fashions, and hearts were no longer worn. -Jean Cocteau

For over 8 years I've been making CDs for 3 of my cousins for their birthdays. They started out sort of as novelty birthday cards, but have progressed into complete package design projects with a real mix CD. Luckily for me the birthdays are spread out evenly throughout the year, so I have enough time to prepare for each one. These are just the front covers of the CDs: some of them don't really show what they actually look like. One of them pops up into a 3-D box; one opens up like a little file folder; one has a cut-out window with replaceable inserts. They are printed on acetates, construction paper, Japanese art paper, velum, card stock... they all have their own story. They also generally get better, hopefully, from a design perspective: I was 15 when I started. Yeah album covers!

...or where my Christmas bonus may go: a Polaroid Spectra System (ideally with a close-up lens) The Polaroid Book Pierrot le Fou U&lc: Influencing Design & Typography Girls With Guitars compilation Crumbling The Antiseptic Beauty by Felt any poster by M/M (Paris) 2-disc reissue of Closer

As you may know, I have more than just a thing for album covers. Since I often find myself in CD stores, I've seen more than a few this year... a lot of which are instantly forgettable, but sometimes I come across a really impressive and complete piece of design. And here are 12 of them. These covers are a good indication of the kind of design I like: - maximalist illustration - pictures of rooms filled with stuff - collages - hand-drawn typography - cleverly used Helvetica

The Go! Team - Proof Of Youth Wiley - Playtime Is Over The Enemy - We'll Live And Die In These Towns Deerhoof - Friend Opportunity Tracey Thorn - Out Of The Woods Efterklang - Under Giant Trees Menomena - Friend And Foe Hisato Higuchi - Butterfly Horse Street Sunset Rubdown - Random Spirit Lover Pat Metheny and Brad Mehldau - Metheny Mehldau Quartet Wolf & Cub - Vessels Panda Bear - Person Pitch (my favourite!)
we had a little impromptu photo shoot tonight.
i can't stop listening to 1970s Beach Boys: Only With You Lady Lynda A Day In The Life Of A Tree
just a few amazing performances i have marked as youtube favourites. Margaret Leng Tan Kraftwerk Young@Heart Stevie Wonder The Residents Queen Throbbing Gristle PJ Harvey

streetcar wires are fun to look at. we looked at them for minutes on end. walking past the laceratory. hand-painted signs add character to a city. even if they forget the apostrophes. Pete knows where they belong. the friendly bookstore cat. . painting a new house feels like starting over again. this was before we found the dead rat in the furnace. . Shrek: the stage adaptation. naptime in the theatre. making faces at the screen door. album cover outtake. free wind machine. i always dress up when i go to the park. others put on stage make up. the sun was slowly setting. it made it hard to focus. attempted handstand. lost cowboy. a monkey and a frog. . yellow cardigans are in this year too cool for school.

THURSDAY

I was sitting not more than 50 feet away from the Postsecret event on Thursday, but I was in my psych class, on the other side of the wall where secrets were being projected. I managed to catch the tail end of the book signing, but I'm still disappointed I missed the presentation. I could hear strains of Camera Obscura's "Tears For Affairs" during the lecture, and it made me sad.

However, before class, I went to a new record store called Hits and Misses. It specializes in mostly punk, hardcore and "crust" (yeah, I'm not sure either), but I picked up a Xiu Xiu/Dead Science split 7" and "Idea" by the Bee Gees on CD.

FRIDAY

During the day Matthew and David and I worked on the Lego movie. I seem to get easily distracted when I play with Lego. I ended up making a Lego man without legs, who happened to be a policeman, rescuing another Lego man, caught on the camera cord, with a vine. But after the shoot David and I went down by the water to see the lights. These 20 spotlights pulsated and moved around depending on your heartbeat and its intensity. There were 10 stations that you held onto with both hands controlling the spotlights and 10 that were reacting to the first 10. So cool! David managed to hit the CN Tower with his heart. Mine wasn't as accurate.

We decided to walk along the lake because it was a nice night.

SATURDAY

In the morning, we were walking along Queen E. because Couple Magazine had an open house, but we stumbled upon a little art sale under some white tents in a small park. I had just bought The Mothers of Invention's "Weasels Ripped My Flesh" and I received my second comment about it there. The first was from a 60ish-year-old-man with a crazy beard/mustache going on in a convenience store. He told me he remembered Zappa when he was just getting started. "'66, I think it was" he told me. And his first album was indeed released that year! David paid for his banana popsicle and we were on our way. It was a photographer's friend under one of the white tents who also noticed the record through my bag. She told me she knew someone who looked like Zappa, and that it was difficult to take him seriously. But then again Zappa never drank or did drugs and was perhaps one of the smartest musicians ever. Anyway we later ended up downtown and looked at the inflatable sculptures.

And after David left I decided to go see if Sam's had a inventory clearance sale going yet. But they didn't so I walked to Yonge-Dundas Square where I saw old dancing men, crazy drummers, a human scupture, and children running through the water fountains. (One of these got me photo of the day in Torontoist!)
Oh, and then I caught a bit of the opening ceremonies of the museum opening. It took me half an hour to walk a quarter of a block, there were so many people, but it was nice to know that Toronto was alive and well. And the new crystal looks amazing when its lit with blue lights.
SUNDAY
I decided to go back to the East end and go to some places in the city I'd never been before. My day was mostly spent at the Riverdale Farm, amongst the families and tourists who were all well-prepared for rain, but hoping it would stay away. I spent a lot of time with the sheep and ducks as well as the goats. The horses were nice to me too although most of the animals looked tired. Saturday must have been busy for them.
Just across the street is Necropolis, Toronto's oldest cemetery, so I took pictures of the beautifully worn epitaphs until it started to rain. But really, it should always be raining in cemeteries.
I eventually made it to my restaurant for a late dinner. Tamarind chicken and a mango shake never tasted so good! Today I hung around the house and started panning out my website. Tomorrow is school, and I'm going to visit a cupcake store.

So for those of you who don't know, my thesis project ended up being a study in the narratives of sexuality that get assigned to children. The way in which I chose to illustrate my findings was to produce a series of t-shirts. I went to Value Village, where the children's t-shirts are $2.00 each, and then printed conflicting (or ironic or cheeky or affirming) messages overtop of them in Futura Extra Bold. I used t-shirts because everyone wears them, and are a family-friendly piece of clothing, but also because they have a history of subversion and rebellion. I really like how the ink of the transfers seeped in differently for each shirt, making some harder to read than others. The words I chose to print directly on top of the screen prints are mine, but the slogan-like quality of some of them came from artists such as Barbara Kruger. (The typeface came from Stanley Kubrick's title sequences.) I wanted it to be immediately recognizable what I was sort of trying to say with these shirts, but less obvious the more time you looked at them. This was definitely a different kind of graphic design project. Below are spreads from the book I produced as a kind of answer key to the t-shirts.

contraceptives, or possibly cyborgs. no joke. first, more safe sex would solve a lot of the world's problems by a considerable amount. try to picture how much a human consumes, breathes, and pollutes in a lifetime. even just one life's worth of carbon dioxide exhaled and food eaten would probably fill more football fields than expected. wouldn't a less populated earth be more sustainable? i can't even tell if i'm being facetious. some of this thinking came from reading a bit of post-human theory. while often fairly ridiculous and unfocused, some of the writing in this area can be quite insightful, and led me to a slightly different take on this. from Donna Harraway's A Cyborg Manifesto: "Sexual reproduction is one kind of reproductive strategy among many, with costs and benefits as a function of the system environment. Ideologies of sexual can no longer reasonably call on notions of sex and sex role as organic aspects in natural objects like organisms and families." so maybe if we stop being monogamous and having "families" as we understand them, stop pretending that gender is a valid classification, and wonder what it would be like to skip the step of original unity, humans could exist in a world indistinguishable from their own bodies. let me put it another way. there is nothing about being "female" that naturally binds women. there isn't really such as state as "being" female. your personal reality is only known to yourself, but the integration of machine into human is something knowable. if humans become what they create, do people become architecture? could this human landscape effectively solve melting icebergs and ozone holes? to quote Donald Kaufman, "you are what you love, not what loves you." maybe we need to love ourselves more, and, in doing so, love our world.

The first night I slept in a cabin, in a sleeping bag on a double bed. Although I awoke early the next morning the sun was already up.
I considered the differences that emerge in the repetition of the same sights smells and sounds.















The Innocence Mission - Somewhere A Star Shines For Everyone

well it's done. i spent three days walking around the 6 floors of OCAD (mostly) impressed by the talent and creativity of 520 graduating students. when i wasn't doing that, i was hanging around my station answering any questions, and sometimes just eavesdropping in on what people had to say about my work. so far no job offers yet. but i did get a phone call from some guy in high school who said "um, i like your business card" and hung up. they were fairly strict about enforcing the no photography rule, but i managed to sneak a few:

and then we went to grandma and grandpa's for chinese food and cupcakes:
i walked up Spadina today and took pictures of interesting typography that caught my eye. letterforms really are very interesting and beautiful in their own way:

i accidentally overexposed almost all my pictures today because of the macro lens. i'm still not quite used to it yet. however, the blown-out parts sort of capture how today felt better than any correctly exposed picture. normally i'd take a cloudy day or a looming thunderstorm over cloudless sunniness, but today was lovely.

we had a belated Easter dinner at grandma and grandpa's yesterday. there's now a puppy in the family! his name is Casey. (but uncle Jamie wanted to call him Pitou, haha) he's a cutie grandma spent days just setting the table... and there was more food than we could eat and we all had a lovely dinner Jonathan shot some baskets, but the hoop that grandpa attached to a wooden beam came loose Jeremy tried to fix it one more of Casey we played some wii as well, but i didn't take any pictures. (that lookalike game is impossible!) the end.
